vignette: Leroy is a 34 year old male, whose chief complaint is, “I am having intrusive thoughts.” Leroy reports that “since childhood, I have been experiencing intrusive thoughts.” He reports he has met with a number of psychiatrists in the past, and has tried a range of different psychiatric medications. Leroy reports he was recently recommended by his present physician to see a psychiatrist again, given how distressing his intrusive thoughts have become. His previous psychiatrist started him on Zoloft, and gave him recommendation for community based mental health psychotherapist.  Leroy has been taking the Zoloft (200 mg daily) for about 5 years, for what he states his provider thought was “anxiety or depression.” Leroy acknowledges history of periods of “sadness”, stating “yeah sad, sometimes, but not depressed; when things get out of control; its been a while though; when something feels out of reach.” Denied present or past suicidal ideation, and denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Leroy insists no problems with perceptual distortion or paranoia, and denied thought insertion or thought broadcasting.  Leroy stated that the intrusive thoughts, “first started happening when I was a kid, I was able to cope with them; getting better understanding what they were; ways to get them to go away; calm myself down and regain control and go on with my life; now that is not working.” Leroy states the most recent intrusive thought has been a fear that the chart bus he drives from his local airport to downtown stop will “slide off the road because of ice or snow.” He thinks about this, on average, about 30 to 45 minutes a day.  Leroy endorsed episodes of “panic” and “my body almost feels like its paralyzed; I experience pain from my spine up”, which lasts for a couple of days at a time. With regards to “generalized anxiety”, patient reports “I would have these thoughts about my ailing mother; she has schizophrenia; my body would react to whatever I was thinking about her; my body tenses up when that happens.” Leroy denied any preoccupations about his physical health, nor inability to leave the home because of anxiety. He reports to work regularly, and rarely misses any work unless he is very sick. He says he is never late to work or planned appointments. Leroy has a girlfriend, and says that relationship is going “great.” In his spare time, he continues to join his friends for basketball pickup games and video game nights, which he still enjoys. Leroy does remember a feeling of having to tap the door handle a few times before he opens it, but said this never lasted more than a few second and was not associated with any fear of catastrophic consequences if he did not complete the task.  Leroy acknowledges observed violence/abuse of his parents when growing up, and with harsh parenting to his 3 siblings, patient denied problems with flashbacks, nightmares or hypervigilance associated with the trauma. Patient works second shift, gets home around 1:30 a.m., reports falling asleep at 2:30 a.m. and wakes up at 10/11 a.m., and can typically sleep through the night without interruption. He reports his energy level is “normal through the week.” Denied recent or past mania. Reports contributing stressors are “work --- not the most peaceful environment.” Also reports mother suffers from “type of schizophrenia and for a while she was taking medication and just recently now decided to stop; that’s been going on for quite some time.” Leroy’s urine toxicology returned with marijuana, and TSH level was within normal limits.
diagnosis: Obsessive compulsive disorder (F42.8)

vignette: Emil is a 22 year old male that reports “my mom wanted us to meet because she spent her whole first therapy session talking to another therapist at her new program about how she feels I need help; I suspect it has to do with my multiple sclerosis (MS), recently losing my fiancé (Lizzy), and after loosing my dog that came with my fiancé. I also lost my career as a farmer.” The patient reports “My girlfriend and I had a good relationship when I used to be able to fish with her; she was a blue blood from the Cape.” Patient reports that he survived being “attacked when I was at a local bar about 4 years ago; the guy smashed a few beer bottles on my head; I had to go to the hospital and they did brain scans; I don’t remember what they said they found.” Patient reports that after that attack, he stopped fishing and started drinking alcohol heavily, at least 8 standard drinks per day, resulting in him missing work, the end of his relationship with his girlfriend, and resulted in getting two DUIs. Patient remembers, “I tried cutting down, but I was never able to do it.” The patient has been sober from alcohol for 76 days now. He denied any other drug use. Patient reports that around two years ago, “I was starting having another MS flare, I stopped being able to sleep for about two weeks and felt angry all the time.” Patient reports during that time he took several last minute trips to Baltimore by train, trying to start a new business and during that time had many sexual indiscretions. He states “people said I was acting strange and that I claimed I was a celebrity that was going to find a cure for autism.” Emil states “I felt like I had endless energy and could take on the world.” The patient reports no similar episodes like that since then, and denied any major mood symptoms since that time. Emil denied recent or past hallucinations, paranoia or thought insertion. Emil reports he never experienced trauma, with the exception of losing his girlfriend and dog. The patient denied any recent problems with depressed, sad, or hopeless mood, and denied problems recent problems with decreased need for sleep and associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or feelings of euphoria. He denied recent or past anxiety or panic, nor OCD.

vignette: Neveah is a 14 year old girl that comes to her pediatrician with her mother (presently 4 months pregnant) due to “out of control behaviors at home.” The patient appears restless in the exam room and requiring redirection from her mother throughout the visit. The patient frequently punches her mother in the legs, and in the stomach, and the patient even threw her ipad at the pediatrician when she asked the patient what was upsetting her. Most of the patients psychiatric history is gathered from her mother, given how irritable the patient is during the exam. The mother reports Neveah was born 8 weeks pre-mature, spent about 1 month in the neonatal intensive care unit due to problems with breathing, and ultimately discharged home to her care at one month of age. The patient met developmental milestones on or near expected time, and was “clingy” when she was a toddler, but had no problems making friends in daycare and grade school. When patient was about 11 years of age, her biological father left the home to join the military, and has deployed ever since. Around 12 years of age, around summertime, the patient appeared much more talkative, energetic, and would go several days only needing about 3 hours of sleep at night. She was more impulsive during these times, and believed she had super powers to “make her friends get in trouble at school”, even when she was not at school herself. She was never tired the following day. During that same period, she had many temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day of the week, that seemed disproportionate to circumstances, like having to have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich instead of a peanut butter and fluff sandwich. The tantrums would last several hours in a day. This pattern of behavior would last for several weeks at a time, with periods of months returning to normal mood and behavior. The patient never appeared to be hallucination or responding to internal stimuli, and never appeared sad or depressed. Neveah had to be hospitalized during an episode like this when she was 13 years old. Neveah refuses to take medications for her symptoms. The start of this year academic year, that patient appeared more calm and in good behavioral control, but began to have similar symptoms of irritability, violence at home, not needing to sleep, talking fast, and property destruction at home.

vignette: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.

vignette: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.

vignette: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.
diagnosis: Polysubstance use disorder, severe (F19.20); Alcohol use, with unspecified alcohol induced disorder (i.e. Beer Pantomania) (F10.99)

vignette: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. Collin’s wife states, “he gets angry of the smallest things.” She goes on to say, “I have to help him get to the bathroom because he is incontinent in the bed very night now”, stating she also has to bath the patient because he can’t find his way around the bathroom. Finally, Collin’s wife states “he goes around making things up when we get around family, sometimes just inventing stuff on the whim, like saying he is making additions to the house or buying a new car, when that is both not true and has nothing to do with the conversation.
diagnosis: Alcohol induced Korsakov’s Syndrome (F10.26); Persistent depressive disorder (F34.1)

vignette: Patient reports "there was an abrasive attack on my life and I was scared; I went into the emergency room; I let my case manager know I was being harassed by my neighbors; people outside of the community; I tried to let as many people know as possible so I could be safe." Patient reports alcohol use disorder history, associated pancreatitis, with increased drinking recently due to "stress of moving and not being able to be with my dog." Patient reports "I came here to get rest." Reports heavy drinking since 12 years of age, with some sobriety on weekends in early 20's. Reports has recently been drinking 3 of the tall boy beers and "a little brandy." Last drink 5 days ago, but reports has been trying to cut back on drinking over the past 2 weeks. One remote seizure when stopped drinking in the past, but more commonly has shaking and "throwing up non stop." Reports "I hear things; its due to harassment; no one else would know", endorsing some negative commentary auditory hallucinations, which started happening about 2 weeks ago. Denied visual hallucinations, but endorsed thought insertion. Patient reports harassment of "voices of old people that I know from Berlin in High School." Patient acknowledges history of depression, with associated anhedonia, withdrawal, low motivation, decreased appetite and problems with concentration, as well as feelings of isolation, including over the past 3 weeks. Denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Acknowledges trauma history, not disclosing details, with associated flashbacks, nightmares and hypervigilance, and “I avoid going to bars now.”  Patient acknowledges period about 2 years ago of decreased need for sleep with associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech and "I was taking care of my mother going through chemotherapy", which resulted in her being involuntarily hospitalized for about 2 weeks. Patient presently denied other stressors at this time.

vignette: Erin is a 16 year old girl that was brought to her pediatric for a routine health exam. Erin is a sophomore at the local high school, plays lacrosse and does ballet at the local arts theatre. Erin reports that she has had no problems with depressed, sad or hopeless mood symptoms, and denied problems with excessive worry or panic. She lives at home with her two mothers, older brother and their dog Fiji. The patient does report that she goes to the gym for about 3 hours each day of the week, during which she does about 2.5 hours of cardiovascular training. She states she skip lunch on most days, has a sliced apple for breakfast, and take her dinner to her bedroom to slowly eat the vegetable portion of dinner (only) over a period of about 3 hours. Menarche was at age 13.5, but she has missed 3 of her last periods. She reports a lot of gastric reflex, and its wakes her up at night time. She also reports “I don’t really have bowel movements anymore, so I take a laxative in the morning and at night time.” She aims to eat less than 1000 calories in a day.

vignette: Amber is a 37 year old woman, that comes to the emergency room with a chief complaint of “I just want to die.” Amber is well known to this emergency room, sometimes coming to the emergency room with suicidal thinking and plans more than 10 times a week. She has been hospitalized over 40 times in the past 5 years. She has a long history of cutting behaviors, which is currently active, and started around 13 years of age. She reports extensive trauma history, including surviving sexual abuse as a adolescent at home, but then also surviving intimate partner violence in subsequent relationships in her adult hood. She reports “constant” flashbacks, nightmares, and hypervigilance, and now avoids any places where “Im the only woman in the room.” The patient reports her current suicidal thoughts and plan to overdose on all of her medications at home is due to “my girlfriend broke up with me out of the blue; she said I’m too much to handle.” The patient reports present mood of “pissed off”, but denied any recent problems or changes in appetite, energy, motivation or enjoying activities she typically enjoys. Denied recent or past mania or psychosis, and she denied problems with heavy alcohol use or street drug use. She acknowledges that “none of my family talk to me anymore; I only had my girlfriend for support.

vignette: Evan is a 62 year old white man, a Harvard Professor in Economics, with a multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use, but recently sober for approximately 7 months after completing substance rehabilitation in an outpatient settings. Evan presented to the emergency room after taking approximately ten 1 mg Klonopin in one setting, he states was “because I was tired and really wanted to go to sleep.” The patient indicates “I was not trying to kill myself” and “I regret taking that number of tablets at once.” He acknowledges recent discord with his wife, stating “I feel very afraid that she is going to leave me whenever we get into arguments, also indicating that after their most recent argument 2 days prior, he relapsed with alcohol use and drank about 6 standard drinks each of the last 2 days, and was intoxicated at the time of overdose. Patient reports “I used to be so active in teaching at Harvard. Now, I feel like I don’t have purpose”, stating that his department at Harvard has been assigning him less teaching or supervising obligations. The patient denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. He denied recent or past symptoms of mania or psychosis. The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He acknowledges that there has been a significant increase in difficulty concentrating on texts he used to be able to attend to without issue. He states “sometimes it feels like I’m walking through mud throughout the day”, and “I want to get back to enjoying things in life again.” He acknowledges “sometimes I find myself just crying, but I have no idea why.” He denied feelings of hopelessness or despair. He denied trauma history, nor symptoms of OCD or panic. On arrival to the emergency room, patient acknowledged that he sustained a fall at home, which lead to his coming to the emergency room for evaluation. The patient is noted to have left peri-orbital ecchymosis and small, well-healing abrasions to his forehead. A head CT in the emergency room reveal a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma. The patient denied headache or vision changes in the emergency room. The emergency room clinician completed paperwork for the patient to be admitted on an involuntary basis to inpatient psychiatry. The following day, a repeat head CT revealed the subdural hematoma appeared 5-7 mm in length, yet the patient continued to deny vision changes, headache, confusion or extremity weakness. The patient reports he has been taking Cymbalta for a history of depression for over 5 years, and denied an untoward side effects.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, moderate, recurrent F33.1; Alcohol use disorder, severe
difficulty: Medium given patient minimizing extent of depression and that overdose was suicide attempt, although endorsing neurovegetative, cognitive, motivation, etc symptoms of depression.

vignette: Melanie is an 11 year old girl who was brought to urgent care by her mother after being sent home from school for “using racial slurs.” Melanie is the product of a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy, vaginally delivered with normal APGAR (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration) score at birth. Melanie used her first word “Momma” around 48 months of age, and didn’t start noticing other children playing with her until about 6 years old. Even at 6 years old, Melanie would not respond to her name when called, often appearing like she was in a daydream, and would often do a lot of “rocking” or “spinning” when anxious. Melanie’s mother indicates “Melanie is a unique kid. She doesn’t really make good eye contact with me, her father or her friends, and seems to be overly focused on doing puzzles all day. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.

vignette: Patient is a 59-year-old female with an unassessed complex trauma history presenting with not-just-right sensations related to hair and bumps growing on her face that cause substantial distress, despite acknowledging that the hairs and bumps are not always physically present. To manage this distress, she keeps tweezers on her person at all times, checks mirrors every 30 minutes when at home, and avoids staying home for extended periods. She also exhibits contamination concerns manifesting as excessive handwashing (25+ times daily) and using barriers to avoid direct contact with "unclean" surfaces out of fear of contracting an illness. Patient believes that she must act on her physical sensations or contamination-related thoughts most of the time or the distress will persist. Patient also collects items like My Little Ponies and Trolls. She has filled her home, garage, basement, a rented warehouse, and now pays to store items in a neighbor's garage despite saying she has little to no money to pay for these expenses. She expresses strong attachment to these possessions, stating she would "NEVER" sell them, and has a history of repurchasing items she previously attempted to sell. Patient's medical history is significant for AIDS (diagnosed 2003, currently on Odefsey), and past surgical interventions following a car accident. Her psychological history includes previous diagnoses of PTSD and Bipolar Disorder (which she disputes). Current symptoms of a major depressive episode include anhedonia, restlessness, sleep disturbance (averaging 4 hours nightly), feelings of worthlessness, and difficulty concentrating. These episodes emerge roughly every few month. The patient denied symptoms of psychosis as well as symptoms related to higher than usual energy or goal-directed activity at any time in the past. She endorsed suicidal ideation without current plan or intent, rating likelihood of attempt at 1%. Social support is reportedly limited, with the patient living alone with her two dogs, having infrequent contact with her daughter, and minimal social connections beyond casual acquaintances while shopping. She denied distress or functional impairment resulting from any traumatic events.

The vignette shows a 59-year-old female with trauma history experiencing significant distress related to her appearance.

**Examining patient behaviors**

The patient shows contamination fears with excessive handwashing, over 25 times daily, and avoids "unclean" surfaces due to fear of illness. She feels compelled to act on her contamination-related thoughts and sensations to prevent distress. Additionally, she collects characters like My Little Ponies and Trolls, filling her home and other storage spaces, despite financial struggles. She strongly refuses to sell these items, even repurchasing previous possessions. Her medical history includes an AIDS diagnosis and past surgical interventions after a car accident, along with disputed psychiatric diagnoses of PTSD and bipolar disorder.

**Reviewing symptoms of depression**

The patient exhibits symptoms of a major depressive episode, such as anhedonia, restlessness, sleep disturbances averaging 4 hours a night, feelings of worthlessness, and trouble concentrating, occurring every few months. She denies any psychotic symptoms or elevated energy levels in the past. While she endorses suicidal thoughts, her risk is low, estimating a 1% chance of an attempt. Her social support is limited, living alone with two dogs, having infrequent contact with her daughter, and minimal social connections. Key psychiatric syndromes to consider include OCD, depressive episodes, contamination obsessions, and possible trauma.

**Analyzing symptoms of OCD and BDD**

The patient experiences classic OCD symptoms, including recurrent, intrusive thoughts about contamination and fear of illness from unclean surfaces, leading to excessive handwashing over 25 times a day and using barriers to avoid contact. She feels driven to act on these thoughts to alleviate distress. There are also indications of compulsions, like checking mirrors every 30 minutes and carrying tweezers, showing good insight into her condition. However, it's important to differentiate this from body dysmorphic disorder (BDD), which focuses on perceived appearance defects and related behaviors.

**Distinguishing OCD and BDD symptoms**

The patient experiences "not-just-right" sensations about hair and bumps on her face, indicating possible preoccupation with physical sensations rather than just appearance. Her compulsions include mirror checking and using tweezers, which align with grooming behaviors seen in body dysmorphic disorder (BDD). However, her contamination fears manifest through OCD, evident in excessive handwashing and the need for barriers to avoid illness. 

Diagnoses to consider include OCD, hoarding disorder, recurrent major depressive disorder, and potentially BDD or somatic symptom disorder. Each diagnosis needs careful consideration based on her symptoms and insights.

**Finalizing top diagnoses**

Given all the details, it seems the primary diagnosis could still be OCD, but BDD might be a secondary concern due to overlapping features. I’ll list the top five diagnoses based on what's evident: 

1. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) - F42  
2. Hoarding Disorder - F42.3  
3. Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, unspecified - F33.9  
4. Body Dysmorphic Disorder - F45.22  
5. Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) - F43.10

vignette: Patient is a 24-year-old gender fluid individual with a BA in creative writing and sociology who is currently living with their parents while taking courses part-time and seeking employment. They describe their living situation as "overwhelming" due to parental boundary issues, though they maintain a supportive romantic relationship since 2019. Their psychiatric history includes diagnoses of MDD and GAD at age 15-16, PTSD in 2016 following emotional abuse by high school friends, and ADHD in 2018 (without neuropsychological evaluation). Current medications include Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018), various supplements, and a contraceptive injection. They previously tried multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) but discontinued each after approximately two weeks due to suicidal ideation and, in one case, motor disturbances. The patient consumes alcohol socially (3-5 drinks monthly) and has been vaping marijuana 1-3 times weekly for three months primarily to aid sleep and manage anxiety. The patient's primary symptoms onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs along with perfectionism through rewriting notes until they felt "just right". Currently, they experience significant distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, which would cause severe distress if interrupted. This "not just right" feeling impairs their ability to meet deadlines, complete job applications, and fulfill social obligations. They also engage in checking behaviors when packing (counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items) and experience distressing sexual intrusive thoughts. Additionally, the patient exhibits skin-picking behaviors, spending over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching their neck and jaw during conversations, and tearing at cuticles, with symptoms worsening during periods of anxiety. They've attempted to stop by wearing pants constantly but have been unsuccessful. The patient has a significant history of depression with three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, and 2017) and self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017). They currently experience passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, and concentration problems, though they report 0% chance of self-harm in the next three months. Social anxiety manifests as persistent fear of judgment and rejection, with distressing rumination about social interactions and excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost them friendships. The patient also reported past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months but denied PTSD symptoms. They disclosed a history of binge eating episodes. During the binge, they ate more rapidly than normal and felt disgusted and embarrassed after. After these eating binges, pt fasted for ~3 days. These eating binges occurred <1 time per week, and the patient has not engaged in these behaviors in the past 2 months.

vignette: The patient is an 18-year-old non-binary college freshman with a complex psychiatric presentation. They report a history of childhood anxiety, perfectionism, and ritualistic self-punishment behaviors starting in the third grade. Currently, their most debilitating symptom is anxiety about "contaminated air" when others cough or sneeze, prompting them to cover their face and hold their breath even when the trigger is far away or on television. They engage in checking and counting behaviors based on the number 3, including checking mirrors while driving, locking/unlocking their car, and tapping their toothbrush. These compulsions are experienced as uncontrollable, with the patient reporting they sometimes modify behaviors (like holding an imaginary door handle in their pocket) when the original compulsion would be disruptive. At approximately age 16, the patient developed anorexia nervosa, restricting their food intake and ultimately requiring intervention from parents and a treatment team. Despite gaining weight under external pressure, the patient continues to restrict eating, has a distinct fear of gaining weight, becoming fat, fasting until dinner, drinking coffee to intentionally upset their stomach. Their BMI currently falls within the normal range. Around the same time their eating disorder developed, the patient experienced depressive symptoms including hopelessness, low motivation, and self-harm behaviors (pulling hair, cutting, punching stomach). They had suicidal ideation during high school, including thoughts of jumping in front of a train and fantasizing about wandering into hallways during a school shooting. Current suicidal thoughts are less frequent and persistent. Current depressive symptoms have been subsyndromal (though not entirely absent) for about 7 months. Specifically, the patient currently denies experiencing depressive symptoms for more than a few hours every couple of weeks but rates their chance of self-harm in the next three months at 50% (suicide attempt chance at 0%). They report minimal alcohol and marijuana use. Notably, the patient expresses resistance to treatment, stating that "getting better means getting fat" and feeling they need to "stay sad for a while longer".

vignette: The patient is a 22-year-old female from the Southeastern United States with a history of Depression (2019), Anxiety (2019), and OCD (March 2021). She recently transitioned from working as a childcare specialist to self-employment as a freelancer. Her medical history includes anemia and IBS, for which she takes daily iron supplements. The patient previously attempted treatment with Zoloft (10mg) for OCD symptoms but discontinued due to emotional blunting effects. She reports consuming alcohol 1-2 glasses a few times monthly and using marijuana daily when available, which she finds helpful for intrusive thoughts despite occasionally triggering anxiety. The patient's most distressing symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about sexually harming children, accompanied by physiological responses that she describes as "groinal". These thoughts were particularly distressing during her work as a childcare specialist, where she engaged in compulsive staring at children's genital areas to "prove" she wasn't sexually attracted to them and sometimes avoided changing diapers due to fear of sexual arousal. After experiencing an intrusive dream about sexually harming her brother in January 2021, she experienced physical symptoms (shaking, freezing) when interacting with him and subsequently increased their time together as a form of reassurance. Additionally, the patient reports significant health anxiety focused on getting cancer, HIV, and STIs, leading to excessive symptom research. The patient experiences panic attacks (1-2 times monthly) lasting 15-30 minutes when triggered by intrusive thoughts, with symptoms including shortness of breath, crying, sweating, racing heart, chest pain, and feelings of detachment. She reports seeking reassurance from her mother when these thoughts become overwhelming. The patient also endorses distressing and functionally impairing social anxiety in small groups, leading to significant avoidance; however, she stated that this anxiety is primary due to her unwanted/intrusive thoughts rather than a fear of being judged. She reports experiencing over 50 depressive episodes in the past year, each lasting at least two weeks with symptoms including decreased appetite, sleep disturbance, fatigue, guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death. She described these episodes as challenging to manage, but "not completely debilitating".
diagnosis: OCD, mild, fair insight, with panic (F42.2); Illness Anxiety Disorder (F45.21); Major Depressive Episode, recurrent, moderate (F33.1)

vignette: Erik is a 10-year-old male who recently completed 4th grade in a gifted math program. He lives with his biological parents and seven-year-old brother, with whom he has "constant" conflict including arguing, screaming, and hitting. Erik has a developmental history of severe temper tantrums prior to age 4, with behavioral challenges emerging in kindergarten and worsening in subsequent grades. His mother reports that her son engages in "constant defiance", experiences rapid mood changes, and demonstrates impulsive behavior, including occasional incidents of pulling knives (though never pointing them at anyone). Daily arguments at home frequently escalate to physical aggression, particularly with his mother and brother. Erik has expressed statements such as "I wish I could go to sleep and never wake up" and reports feeling depressed "randomly" a couple times per month since second or third grade, though he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. Erik's behavioral difficulties have manifested in both home and school environments. In school, he has engaged in speaking out of turn, refusing to follow directions, agitating teachers, and having "screaming matches" with staff. Despite these challenges, Erik maintains high grades across subjects (with math being his most difficult class at a B), has several friends, and is described as a leader in social interactions. He has a Section 504 plan that allows for movement opportunities and frequent breaks when needed. In March 2019, Erik began taking 2mg of Guanfacine (extended release) for attention/concentration deficits, which has helped reduce impulsivity and improve behavioral control, though aggressive and defiant behaviors have continued. His mother reports implementing a point system for rewards and consequences but notes limited effectiveness due to inconsistent expectations between parents. Formal assessment indicates that Erik demonstrates a pattern of emotional dysregulation, defiance, and aggressive behavior, with physical aggression occurring approximately every other day at home. Assessment also confirms prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are present across settings and contribute to emotional dysregulation and academic underperformance relative to ability.
diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Moderate (F91.3); Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Type (F90.2)

vignette: Dole is a 31-year-old male who arrived for intake with an extensive psychiatric history dating back to age 17, with multiple hospitalizations and diagnoses including Mood Disorder NOS, Bipolar Disorder, Narcissistic Personality Disorder, Schizoaffective Disorder, and Asperger's Syndrome. His symptoms have included paranoid ideation, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusions (such as believing television was sending special messages), obsessive thoughts, compulsive behaviors, and periods of mania and depression. Dole holds a master’s degree in computer science and previously developed cybersecurity systems but resigned in 2019 due to unmanageable anxiety. He currently lives with his parents, who provide significant assistance with daily activities. Throughout his treatment history, Dole has demonstrated paranoid thoughts beginning at age 19, with recurrent episodes of acute psychosis requiring hospitalization. In 2018, he experienced hallucinations of messages on his phone, and in 2019, he reported seeing "the devil" and experiencing auditory hallucinations. He endorses unwanted/intrusive thoughts causing anxiety, which he attempts to neutralize with repetitive behaviors that take 1-3 hours daily. His symptoms include fear of harming himself, violent imagery, concerns about germs, and moral preoccupations. Dole reports deficits in procedural and episodic memory, impairing self-care and accurate recollection of past events. His family history is positive for paternal psychosis, depression with possible bipolar disorder, and a completed suicide. Intake impressions indicate that Dole has experienced (and continues to experience) delusions, hallucinations, disorganized/catatonic behavior, diminished emotional expression, and amotivation within a one-month period. He has exhibited delusions or hallucinations for at least two weeks in the absence of major mood episodes, and his functioning has decreased notably compared to his pre-symptom baseline. Regarding his unwanted/intrusive thoughts, he demonstrates limited insight.
diagnosis: Schizophrenia, Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Episode (F20.9); Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight (F42.2)

The patient initially denied but later acknowledged experiencing unwanted sexual thoughts regarding his sexual orientation. This behavior has significantly impaired his functioning, causing him to lose multiple jobs within the past year, avoid family gatherings, limit time in public, and experience relationship strain with his girlfriend of 12 years, with whom he has three children and now stays home while she works. The patient experiences moderate suicidal ideation, including thoughts that he would be better off dead, and reports feeling worthless and guilty, particularly about "not providing for my children and for staring". While the patient endorsed panic attacks on assessment, follow-up questioning revealed these occur specifically when thinking excessively about his staring behaviors or unemployment, rather than occurring spontaneously. vignette: A 32-year-old male with a past medical history of polysubstance use disorder (cocaine, marijuana, and methamphetamine) presents for bizarre behavior brought in by emergency medical services (EMS) after a neighbor called to report that patient was outside her home threatening her with a knife. Per neighbor's report, the patient had been yelling about the FBI and demanding to be let into her home while waving a knife. Patient was yelling at paramedics enroute and attempted to punch a paramedic when being loaded into the ambulance. Upon arrival to the emergency room, patient was agitated, requiring emergency intermuscular injection of medications to deescalate. Patient told doctors in the emergency room that he felt unsafe and needed them to watch his knives for him. He felt like the government was going to come get him and use the weapons in his home against him. He recalls going to the neighbor's home in an attempt to have her hide his knives for him. A few hours later, the psychiatry team came to evaluate the patient, at which point the patient appeared drowsy and asked to be left alone due to feeling tired. He refused to provide urine sample but allowed a blood draw. His blood work returned with elevated white blood count (WBC) at 18 x10e3/uL. He denied having any prior psychiatric diagnoses but admitted that he has been using methamphetamine recently. He recalls he had been admitted to an inpatient psychiatry service before, around 1 year prior after using meth, where he stayed for 3 days and was discharged on Seroquel, which patient denied currently taking. He does not recall his diagnosis from that admission. Patient agreed to receive further care at a psychiatric facility and was voluntarily transferred to an inpatient psychiatry unit. Patient was started again on Seroquel but refused to take it during admission. He was seen napping during the day and reported some stomach cramping to the treatment team. By day 3 of admission, patient reported feeling well and signed himself out of the hospital.
diagnosis_icd: Other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance-induced psychotic disorder with delusions (F19.150)
reasoning: Patient only has known history of 1 prior episode of psychosis, which appeared to be in the setting of substance use (meth). Patient this time also admitted to using meth recently. While urine sample was not obtained, an elevated WBC can be indicative of methamphetamine use in the absence of infection. Additionally, fatigue and gastrointestinal upset are common symptoms of stimulant withdrawal. Resolution of symptoms in a short course of only 3 days and without medication is another evidence for substance-induced psychosis rather than a primary psychotic disorder. However, with such limited history, an underlying primary psychotic disorder cannot be fully ruled out and thus antipsychotic treatment may still be indicated.

vignette: A 16-year-old male in the 9th grade with no known past psychiatric history presented as a walk-in admission to the county psychiatric hospital with his mother. He started seeing a therapist recently after mom noticed that he was talking to her less and appeared less energetic. Mom reports that the patient has also been behaving oddly, accusing downstairs neighbors to be trying to spy on him and talking poorly about him. She also reports that he told her he feels unsafe because people are trying to harm him. She also noticed that he has been more irritable, occasionally punching walls but never people. When patient was interviewed directly, he appeared constricted and dysphoric, with hair covering his eyes. He spoke softly. He reported that he has been feeling angry because he has been thinking more about how his biological father used to abuse his mom, even though his biological father no longer is in their life. He reports that he has been experiencing poor memory, poor concentration, feeling anxious and ruminating frequently. He also admits to having thoughts of death several months ago and does have access to guns although he has never attempted to kill himself. He does report that he intentionally cut his wrist a few months ago to cope with his feelings but denied having suicidal intent. He also endorses poor sleep and low mood. He admits that he is a long-time bars user (referring to Xanax) but does not know the dosage and is evasive when asked about his frequency and most recent use. He also reports that he smokes marijuana but again does not provide details regarding his use. He states that more recently, he started using marijuana specifically to help with new-onset paranoia. He describes his mind playing tricks on him, morphing objects into faces leading to feeling scared. Lab work collected at the hospital did not show abnormalities other than a positive urine cannabinoid screen. Patient was started on fluoxetine for his depression symptoms and aripiprazole for his psychotic symptoms and he improved after a week on this medication combination, reporting better mood and no longer feeling paranoid.
diagnosis_dsm: Major depressive disorder, severe, with psychosis
diagnosis_icd: Major depressive disorder, severe, with psychosis (F32.3); Cannabis dependence (F12.20); Xanax use disorder, severe, with dependence (F13.232)
reasoning: Patient appears to have both symptoms of depression and psychosis. However, since it appears that the depressive symptoms appeared first (several months ago) with the psychotic features appearing later on with the severity of depression (more recently, new-onset), the diagnosis would be MDD with psychosis rather than a primary psychotic disorder such as schizoaffective disorder. The patient also has demonstrated cannabis use and Xanax dependency.

vignette: A 14-year-old male patient with a history of generalized anxiety disorder is brought to his pediatrician for a skin exam after she saw the patient wiping his skin down with a Clorox wipe. She reports that since the start of COVID in 2020, patient has been more vigilant about keeping his space and belongings clean, wiping down his devices upon returning from any outing, wiping down doorknobs, light switches, and bathroom counters daily. She states that initially, he feared catching COVID. However, she states it has been 3 years of such behaviors and believes that his cleaning behaviors have actually intensified. She noticed that he started washing his hands more often, sometimes showering multiple times in a day, and last week, saw him use a Clorox disinfecting wipe to clean his body. She became concerned for the potential of chemical irritation on his skin. When patient was addressed directly, patient reports that he needs everything to be clean. He expresses an intense fear that his belongings and space are contaminated with germs if he does not clean then regularly. He alludes to his view of the outside as “dirty” and that his room is “clean.” He feels the intense urge to have anything that enters his room to be decontaminated otherwise his whole room will become contaminated. He describes an intense feeling of anxiety if he cannot clean things before they enter his room. He states that he spends a lot of time washing his hands because if he misses a spot or brushes his hand against the side of the sink, he needs to start over to ensure that they are fully clean. He endorses similar patterns with showering and wiping down belongings, often needing to start over to ensure he did not miss any spots and has fully decontaminated. He does mention that he has been struggling in school due to having less time to study with his cleaning obligations.

vignette: Patient is a 23-year-old male patient with a past psychiatric history of anxiety and depression who is hospitalized for a suicide attempt 2 days ago during a fight with his girlfriend. He reports that he took a handful of pills (escitalopram) that he has prescribed for anxiety. He reports that 2 days ago, his girlfriend was angry at him and suggested that she was thinking about leaving the relationship. The patient reports that he felt very hurt and wanted to show her how much he was hurt by her statement, which is why he took the pills. He described the act as impulsive and wasn’t sure if he truly wanted to die in the moment. He states that he does not regret his decision but also denies any suicidal ideation (SI) currently. He also denies feeling depressed prior to the fight. He states that his friends and loved ones “always” leave him and that he was hurt because he thought his girlfriend was different. When asked about outpatient care, he expressed a mistrust for mental health providers, stating that most of them “just don’t get it” and that he is still working on finding a therapist who understands him. He says that the last clinic assigned him a female provider even though he requested a male provider. He admits that they stated they didn’t have any male providers available at the time, but still feels that they betrayed him by making him false promises. He endorses feeling like he isn’t worth other people’s time and feeling depressed often, especially when relationships or friendships don’t work out. He denies recent insomnia, appetite changes, concentration or memory issues, and anhedonia. He is seen to have multiple healed lacerations on bilateral forearms, which he states are scars from cutting. He asks the provider if they think he may have bipolar disorder or autism because he feels like he gets “mood swings” and has difficulty in keeping friends. vignette: Patient is a 31-year-old female denying any psychiatric history who was transferred to the county psychiatry hospital from a local emergency room for threatening to kill herself. She tells the evaluating psychiatrist that she had gotten into an argument with her husband. She states that she and her husband has been living in a hotel for the past week due to a conflict between her and her mother-in-law. She reports that she feels her husband does not understand nor respect her because he was requesting to return home to be closer to his workplace. She states that she was surprised at the argument because he is usually a “good man.” When asked what made her feel disrespected this time, she replied it was because he was refusing her request to continue staying at the hotel and that he usually never says no to her. When asked her reason for staying, she stated that she just “did not feel ready” to return home yet because being around her mother-in-law stressed her out. She did not understand why her husband was not accommodating her discomfort. However, when pointing out husband’s discomfort with the long commute time to work, she minimized his concern and did not acknowledge his struggle, instead redirecting the conversation to her own feelings. When asked about the reason for her disagreement with her mother-in-law, she states it is because her mother-in-law does not recognize her efforts for contributing to the household. She states that, “My mother-in-law always complains that I don’t do chores and don’t work. But she doesn’t get it that I’m the one supporting my husband at his job and that he should be the main breadwinner anyways as the husband. Besides, I did the dishes today, it’s not even true that I don’t do chores.” When addressing the physicians, she addresses them casually (e.g. “dude,” “man,” etc.) and states to them, “You’re a doctor, you should be smart enough to understand me.” She denies that she has any mental issues that requires her to remain in the hospital, stating that, “Smart people like us, we get misunderstood, you get it right? That’s why they sent me here.” She also alludes to believing that her mother-in-law called the police to have her brought here to get her away from her husband because she’s “jealous I get to spend more time with her son than she does.” When informing her that the reason for her hospitalization was the threat of suicide, she casually waves it off, stating, “Oh, I don’t actually want to kill myself, I just said that to get my husband to listen to me.”
diagnosis_icd: Narcissistic personality disorder (F60.81)
reasoning: Patient demonstrates an expectation to be recognized as superior (like with her mother-in-law), feeling that they are special and can only be understood by smart people like doctors, exploitative behaviors of expecting her husband to go along with her every demand and attempting to manipulate him via suicidal threats when he does not comply, a lack of empathy towards her husband, and believing that her mother-in-law is envious of her. These traits are key features for narcissistic personality disorder.

vignette: Patient is a 10-year-old female who is brought into the walk-in area of a psychiatric hospital for hitting kids at school. The patient is a ward of the state, both of her parents were found to be unfit to care for the child. The guardian received a report from her teacher that the patient slapped a classmate during an argument. The patient is in the 5th grade. She has had many other reports this year for throwing tantrums and getting into fights. Guardian reports that patient has a history of being returned from various foster and adoptive families due to anger and aggression. She states that since the patient has been under her care, she has noticed the patient to be easily irritable with little to no accountability for her own actions, blaming the other kids for annoying her or saying that “I didn’t mean it.” Aggressive outbursts occur multiple times a week. When asked, the patient says that other kids annoy her but is unable to specify examples. She also says that staff and teachers annoy her too. However, she denies hitting them. The patient during the assessment repeated interrupts the guardian and the evaluator saying, “I didn’t do anything,” and begging to be taken home. As guardian shares reports made by the school, the patient interrupts and calls guardian a “liar” and is visibly upset. Patient begs the evaluator to let her go home and not recommend hospitalization. However, when evaluator informed patient that aggression is often a reason for admission, patient suddenly becomes very angry, picking up a tissues box and throwing it at the glass divider between her and the evaluator. When evaluator pointed out her behavior, patient immediately becomes tearful and apologetic, stating,” I didn’t do anything, I didn’t mean it, I didn’t even hit you.” Guardian states that behaviors like this is what she is referring to. Guardian reports that her outbursts are most common when she doesn’t get her way, but that she seems to be irritable in general as well.

vignette: Pt is a 25-year-old female who came was admitted involuntarily to an inpatient psychiatric unit for altered mental status. She is seen to make bizarre movements where she is falling back and rolling on the ground was reported to have not eaten much in the last 4- 5 days and has been just sitting at one spot for most of the day. She minimally engages with you. She was given Lorazepam 2 mg intramuscularly which was helpful to calm her down and she was able to talk more to the team. She reports history of depression and was started on Sertraline 50 mg PO daily. She was compliant to these medications for the past 3 months. She reports she lost her mother with the battle with cancer 3 months ago. She was missing her mom, started to feel depressed, stopped eating much after her death, had problems with sleep, felt hopeless and sometimes would struggle to get through the day with no energy at all. Once, she was started on Sertraline she noticed improvement in her symptoms for the past month. A friend who brought her to the hospital reported for the past week, patient is unable to sleep and has been cleaning her house vivaciously at night, has been going out for walks for 3 hours, has been feeling great with her energy for the past week. She reports patient went out and bought herself a brand-new Mercedes. She is unsure if patient had that much money in her account. She noticed patient just crashing down, feeling more confused since past 2 days where she was mostly altered. Friend reports “she was not making any sense in what she says” and she brought her to the hospital. Her labs showed mild elevation in BUN, creatinine was normal, liver function tests were normal, WBC count normal, low hemoglobin of 10.1 with MCV of 70. Urine drug screen and pregnancy test was negative. Friend reports no other past medical problems or any allergies. She denied any history of substance use.

When a teacher calls on her in school, she becomes “frozen with fear” if she will say something ill-informed or inappropriate. She has hard time engaging with other peers at college. This makes her anxious to the point of getting paralyzed and cannot concentrate on her work. When she goes back home, she can do better. She is calmer and can enjoy time with friends and family. He feels sad and depressed about all these people coming after him. He reports since these people started to follow him, he has been feeling sadder and more depressed. vignette: Pt is a 42-year-old female who came into the emergency room reporting auditory hallucinations for a day that have been telling her to hurt herself. She reports she is not from the city and is traveling for her work. She reports she has past psychiatric history of depression three years back and reports she has been off medications and her symptoms have been well controlled. She started feeling sad now that she is hearing voices, and they are telling her to kill herself and she is worried for her safety. She talked to her mom on the phone and mom asked her to call 911 so she can go the emergency room. She has been staying at the hotel for the past one day. She planned to go to her work for the next couple of days and wanted to look for houses to move to this new city. On admission to the emergency room, she is seen to be very scared, thinks she is in her hometown and that the year currently was her birth year. She was not oriented to time and place. Her blood pressure is 150/90, pulse 110, temp of 98.6, saturation 97 %. She is scared someone will come and hurt her and she will not be able to see her mom again and is often seen to scream her name. She was given Ativan 2 mg intramuscularly along with Haldol 5 mg and Benadryl 50 mg intramuscularly to help calm her down. Emergency contact, her mother was contacted. She reports patient having history of alcohol withdrawal seizures, last seizures were three years ago. She says she has been sober for three years except recently due to stress of work she started to drink more with last drink three days ago. She denied any drug use/ tobacco use. Mom reports she saw her more anxious and stressed out for the past 4-5 days due to work and family stressors. She reports she seemed depressed, was not eating much, just working, sleep was okay, was hopeful her move to the new city will be better for her stress and she will be able to thrive better. She denied any medical problems.

vignette: Patient A is a 27 year old female with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents after 2 days of new-onset paranoia. Two days ago, her husband states that the patient began speaking about her concerns that the neighbors were watching her and that they were out to get her. He also notes that it appears she was hallucinating and internally preoccupied. He states the patient has never done this in the past. On the exam, her thought process is illogical and disorganized, she appears to be responding to internal stimuli. She speaks about being concerned that people are out to get her and that she is worried about her safety. Lab work with CBC, CMP, UDS, UA, thyroid panel, B12, folate, HIV, syphilis are unremarkable. Psychiatry is consulted and starts her on a low dose of Seroquel. After one dose, the patient begins to have worsening psychotic symptoms and an acute dystonic reaction. Benadryl is given for acute dystonia and Seroquel is stopped. CT Head imaging is unremarkable. Suddenly, patient begins having a seizure and is admitted for further work up. EEG shows epileptiform discharges. CT A/P is done; there is suspicion for an ovarian teratoma which is confirmed with abdominal ultrasound. Neurology is consulted, LP is completed and CSF study for anti-NMDA antibody is positive. Pt is admitted to the Neurology service for PLEX.

vignette: Patient B is a 60 year old male with past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, newly diagnosed prostate cancer and a past psychiatric history of anxiety who was admitted to the hospital for cancer treatment. Psychiatry is consulted for depression. The patient has been hospitalized for 7 days now, and the course has been complicated by a DVT. On assessment, the pt appears dysphoric with a constricted affect. He shares that being in the hospital and receiving this new cancer diagnosis has caused a major disruption in his life. Previously, he was still working as a patent lawyer and running his own law firm. He states that since the diagnosis (which he received 1 month ago), his mood has been more depressed with anhedonia, hopelessness, helplessness, low energy, and low appetite which he attributes to the nausea caused by his chemotherapy. He feels constantly worried about his cancer and what will happen to him and his family. The patient is married to his wife for 30 years and has 2 children with 4 grandchildren. He is concerned about the finances, getting his estate planning in order, and worried about what will happen to his wife if he were to pass. He states prior to receiving this diagnosis, he did not have any difficulties with depression. He had a distant history of anxiety when he was in law school, but he states it has since been better controlled with therapy. He has never taken psychiatric medication and never seen a psychiatrist.

vignette: Patient C is a 24 year old male with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents to an inpatient psychiatric hospital after his family filed an emergency detention order to have him hospitalized due to psychosis. The family state the patient has been steadily declining over the past 2 years. They share he was a high-achieving college student and graduated with a degree in electrical engineering. In the past 2 years, he has become more withdrawn, appears more depressed, and his hygiene has declined to the point where he no longer showers. He lost his job due to the fact he was unable to keep up with his duties. In the past 6 months, they’ve noticed the patient’s speech start to become rambled and illogical. They state “it looks like he’s talking to someone not there”. Family history is significant for schizophrenia in the patient’s paternal grandfather. On assessment with the patient, he appears internally preoccupied, withdrawn, and is difficult to engage. His speech is illogical, disorganized, and with increased latency. He is noted to be malodorous with poor hygiene. Lab work-up with CBC, CMP, thyroid panel, HIV, Syphilis, B12, and folate are negative. UDS is positive for marijuana. He is started on Risperidone. After 5 days on the medication, he is less internally preoccupied, able to state he was hearing voices that are still present, but less loud and comprehensible. However, his affect still is flat and he is still mostly withdrawn to his room. His hygiene has improved and he was able to take a shower.

vignette: Patient D is a 16-year-old male with no past medical history and a past psychiatric history of DMDD and ODD who presents to the psychiatric ER after he assaulted his mother. He was brought in accompanied by police officers. The patient was calm, at times defiant towards the physician. When asked what happened, the patient explains that his mother had told him to clean his room, and he did not want to. He was playing video games and did not want to stop. His mother asked again, and he again ignored her. She attempted to take away his video game and, in the process, the patient punched her in the head. He states, “she was being a bitch”. The patient has a history of truancy of school and currently has pending charges for assaulting another student at school starting at age 14. Mother provides collateral history that pt endured sexual abuse at a young age by his biological father who is now in prison. She states that the patient has a problem with authority figures, frequently arguing with her and teachers. She states he will often skip school and run away from home. She mentions he seems “irritable all the time” and when he is told to do something he doesn’t want to, he “explodes”, this started at age 9 and has been on-going. Mother notes that his siblings fear him and shares that the patient frequently hits their household dog, sometimes “too hard”. UDS is positive for marijuana, pt admits to smoking marijuana daily for 1 year.

vignette: Patient E is 25 year old female with past psychiatric history of anxiety and depression who presents to her PCP appointment for an annual follow-up. The PCP conducts a depression screening and patient endorses depressed mood, anhedonia, hopelessness, low energy, difficulty concentrating, and feelings of guilt/worthlessness. She states she has felt like this for most of the day, nearly every day for about 3 weeks now. Prior to these 3 weeks, the patient notes she felt like her mood was “normal”. When asked if she has ever had periods of abnormally elated mood or irritability, she notes that about 1 month ago she had a period where she felt “extremely happy”. States that she felt “the complete opposite” of how she felt currently. States this period lasted for approximately 5 days and she was “so so happy”. She also felt extremely productive during this time, cleaning her entire house in an evening, and that she was able to “take on more projects at work”. She also notes that she had increased energy, needing to only sleep about 2-3 hours a night during that time and feeling “amazing”. She has tried Zoloft in the past but discontinued the medication because it made her feel “hyper”. She currently is not taking any psychiatric medication. She has never been psychiatrically hospitalized before.

vignette: Patient F is a 37 year old male with past medical history of hypertension and past psychiatric history of substance use disorder (marijuana, methamphetamine) and psychosis who presents after being brought in by police to the ED for aggression. The patient was reportedly at a gas station causing a disturbance, speaking about how everyone in there was the devil and throwing items off the shelves. When officers arrived, the patient was aggressive and had to be tased. On arrival, the patient had to receive emergency IM medications of Haldol, Ativan, and Benadryl due to agitation. Psychiatry was consulted for psychosis. On psychiatric assessment, the patient is drowsy after having just received the emergency IM medications. However, he is irritable and hostile, telling the physician to “fuck off” and that “the devil is out to get you”. He states he is “like a God” and that he was unfairly arrested. On chart review, he has a history of being prescribed antipsychotics, but currently pt denies taking any psychiatric medications. Assessment was limited due to the patient’s lack of engagement and hostility. Lab work was significant for UDS positive for marijuana, methamphetamine, and PCP. He started on a low-dose of scheduled Risperidone. The next day, he was reassessed by psychiatry. He is less hostile, but still irritable and asks if he can sleep. On limited assessment, pt denied thinking the devil was after him and did not make any grandiose statements about him being God. He did not appear internally preoccupied but was very sleepy. He was later assessed in the afternoon after he was repotedly asking to leave. He denied suicidal ideations, homicidal ideations, or auditory/visual hallucinations. While he was still irritable, he was more cooperative and states he does not recall being at a gas station. He does endorse to using marijuana, methamphetamine, and PCP “for 2 days straight”. He is currently homeless and wants to go to the shelter. He denies paranoia or any belief that he is God, states “that’s ridiculous” when asked that question. Patient was then discharged after spending 24 hours in the ED.

vignette: Patient G is a 29 year old male with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents to his PCP for problems with sleep. He states he has difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep. He states he has recurring nightmares of what he witnessed while he was in Afghanistan, and these prevent him from sleeping. He also endorses avoidance of any loud noises such as fireworks as it triggers memories for him. He endorses hyper vigilance and always feels like he has to be aware of his surroundings. He states his mood has been “mad” and that he’s “always angry” for no reason and that this has caused difficulties between him and his wife. He does not go into detail about what he witnessed while deployed but does state that he regrets what he did and that he’s “a horrible person”. With regards to substance use, he endorses smoking 1 pack per day of cigarettes and drinking 6-beers a day, denies any illicit substances. He started drinking 6-beers a day ever since he returned from active duty and states “I never miss a day, it’s the only thing that helps me”. Patient was started on Zoloft and Trazodone for sleep and referred to a psychiatrist by his PCP.

vignette: Patient H is a 36 year old female with a history of major depressive disorder (MDD) who presents to an inpatient psychiatric hospital for bizarre behavior. The patient was diagnosed with MDD when she was 20 years old and has been on Zoloft for years. However, she recently lost her insurance and has not been able to take her Zoloft for 6 months. The patient had previously worked full-time as an accountant and was married with 2 children. On assessment, the patient is mute with poor hygiene. Her face at times will scrunch during the interview. She sits motionless in a chair, not answering any questions. She stares blankly at the psychiatrist and is unable to engage. When asked if she can stick her tongue out, she does not follow the simple command. The psychiatrist conducts a musculoskeletal exam and when they move her arm, they are met initially with a large amount of resistance that slowly decreases with time. The psychiatrist moves the patient’s arm above her head, and the pt leaves it there after the psychiatrist lets go.

vignette: Patient I is a 25 year old male with past medical history of hypertension and past psychiatric history of psychosis who presents to a psychiatric clinic for an initial evaluation due to hearing voices. The patient shares that he has been hearing voices for about 1 year. They initially started as incomprehensible whispers but have gradually become louder and more comprehensible. He states sometimes they will be bothersome and make negative remarks about him. He also states he has been isolating himself more and while he previously enjoyed spending time with his friends, he now has no desire to. He currently moved back in with his parents after being laid off from his job as an accountant due to missing multiple days of work unexcused. He denies any depression currently. When asked if he’s ever had episodes of an elated mood or irritability, he does state there was a period in the past year where he felt very happy. He says during this time he didn’t need to sleep as much, maybe 3-4 hours a night, had more energy, was productive, more sociable, and felt more motivated than before. He says people told him that he was “completely different” and people had a hard time understanding his speech, asking him to slow down. He says that lasted for a “couple weeks” and then it “went away”. He was still hearing voices at that time. His speech is tangential at times and he appears internally preoccupied. Hygiene is poor.

vignette: Patient J is a 30 year old male with past medical history of hyperthyroidism and past psychiatric history of psychosis who presents to the inpatient psychiatric hospital after his family filed a community mental health warrant. Per his wife, the patient has not been sleeping for 2 weeks, not showering, yelling constantly at home, and took out their savings suddenly to open a restaurant. She states he has no restaurant experience and currently works as a plumber, never mentioning wanting to open a restaurant. She states he has been more violent at home, hitting her when she does not “do as he says” and endangering their 2 year old son. She gives an example of how he said that their son “should be able to bathe himself” and shut him in the bathroom by himself, not allowing the mother to enter. She also states he has been reaching out to multiple women on Instagram that he has never met before, asking them on a date and sending explicit photos to them. She has also noticed the patient talking to himself when no one is there. On assessment, the patient is irritable, loud, demanding to be released. Speech is rapid and pressured. He states, “nothing is wrong with me, I feel amazing, I am a God, I am the Messiah, you all are nothing”. He states that he has been “appointed” by God to “save humanity” and that he cannot do so while hospitalized. When asked about sleep, he states “I don’t need sleep, that is for the weak, I sleep maybe 1 hour and I feel amazing, I have good rest”. With regards to substance use, he denies cigarettes or alcohol use, does endorse buying delta 8 vapes from the smoke shop and smoking them. The wife states he started smoking these vapes about 6 months ago. He has seen a therapist before for depression but has never taken any psychiatric medications.
diagnosis_dsm: Bipolar I disorder, current episode manic, with psychotic features
